Speaker: swimmer
Dialogue: ...This is your path. There is no other. That's a curse you can use on the Yankee before battle.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: And that works?

Speaker: swimmer
Dialogue: You have to say it in Cherokee.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: You said it to me in Cherokee.

Speaker: swimmer
Dialogue: So keep your head still.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Anyway, there won't be any war. And if there is, they say it won't last a week.

Speaker: rourke
Dialogue: Don't worry, son. Those Yankee boys keep store hours. They ain't open yet.

Speaker: butcher
Dialogue: That's fresh breakfast. Shoot him!

Speaker: rourke
Dialogue: I'm not firing, start the damn war off.

Speaker: rourke
Dialogue: That's my rabbit!

Speaker: butcher
Dialogue: That was something! That's hell and we've been there! Kicked old Nick's asshole.

Speaker: butcher
Dialogue: You got a charge?

Speaker: stobrod
Dialogue: That's gold in his mouth he got no need for.  We take his boots.

Speaker: oakley
Dialogue: I got a few. You saw?

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: I saw.

Speaker: oakley
Dialogue: I know you don't recognise me. I'm Mo Oakley's boy.  It's okay. I was thirteen when you all left. Am I going to die?

Speaker: oakley
Dialogue: I'd like to hear some music while I go.

Speaker: stobrod
Dialogue: What about Bonaparte's Retreat? That's one I play.

Speaker: oakley
Dialogue: Play me something sweet. Like a girl's waiting for me.

Speaker: oakley
Dialogue: Play me something like there's nothing to fear from a merciful Lord.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: You heard him.

Speaker: stobrod
Dialogue: I only know a couple of tunes.

Speaker: oakley
Dialogue: Like when you're thirsty up at Bishop's Creek and the water is so cool.

Speaker: oakley
Dialogue: I'm reaching Cold Mountain before you.

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Don't get up, soldier. You are mentioned tonight in my report. You are a credit to the Highlands, to North Carolina and to the Cause.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Do you have news, sir, on my application for transfer?

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: I know. A bloody day. It's what our General said: Good thing war is so terrible else a man might end up liking it too much.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Sir. It was my understanding the medical corps was desperate for volunteers.

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Right now, soldier, it's me who is in need of volunteers. There's a dozen Yankees in that stand of trees between us. Stuck there from the retreat. Come daylight they can shoot us down for sport.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Ada, how are you settling in? Are you liking the farm?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Very much. It's beautiful country.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: So listen -- if you would say hello to one of these fools, I'll get a field cleared this weekend.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Anyone? Like a forfeit?

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: No. Him in particular, up in the rafters. Been pressing me all morning.

Speaker: rourke
Dialogue: I call this nail: a free nigger.

Speaker: butcher
Dialogue: Show some respect -- these nails are making a church.

Speaker: rourke
Dialogue: I call this nail: respect the church.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I'm Ada Monroe.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: I'm Inman.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Inman?

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: W. P. Inman.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: W. P. Inman.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Repeating a thing doesn't improve it.  People call me Inman.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: If you were to take a glass of lemonade your friends might stop staring. Inman.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: They're not my friends.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: And what do you do?

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: I work wood. Got a piece of land. Mostly work wood.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Clear fields?

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: I can clear a field.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: So, was there something in particular you wished to say to me?

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: I'll say thank you for the lemonade.

Speaker: rourke
Dialogue: Esco loves the Yankees.

Speaker: esco
Dialogue: I prefer a Yankee to a halfwit.

Speaker: esco
Dialogue: What is it you think you'd be fighting for?

Speaker: rourke
Dialogue: The South.

Speaker: esco
Dialogue: And what's that when it's at home?

Speaker: acton
Dialogue: Pop, you causing trouble?

Speaker: esco
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: ellis
Dialogue: That means yes.

Speaker: esco
Dialogue: You cut the wood, you carry the water for good old King Cotton. Now you want to fight for him. Somebody has to explain it to me.

Speaker: acton
Dialogue: Don't even try.

Speaker: butcher
Dialogue: How's the lemonade? Sweet?

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: That's a fine looking thing.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I've been missing it.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Thank you, by the way.  Inman's down in the bottom field, clearing his debt.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Oh dear. And then he had nothing to say.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: He was happy.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Are men so different in Charleston?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Men? I don't know. I don't even know what a woman should be like. In Charleston I was called a thistle, twice, by two different men. Both of them -- they were hunting for a simile, what was I like -- and thistle came right to them.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: If you're saying you might like him, why not go down and say hello.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: Esco, our friends there --  -- they helped build the Chapel?

Speaker: esco
Dialogue: That's Teague and his boys. I'd recommend you kick them out except a man don't kick a snake. One time the Teague family owned the whole of Cold Mountain. My farm, your farm, all belonged to his grand-daddy. Teague wanted this place bad. You got it. He's here sniffing out an advantage.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: There's no advantage here, but to celebrate a job well done. Cheers --  -- and thank you.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Were you planning to come inside?

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: I'm wetter than a fish.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: There's a good fire going.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: I'm all right.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Somebody said you were enlisting.  Are you?

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: If there's a war we'll all fight.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: If there's a mountain we'll all climb, if there's an ocean we'll all drown.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Call a thing a war makes it a challenge to some men.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Did you get a picture made?

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Say again.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: A tintype, with your gun and your courage on display.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: You're laughing at me.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I don't know you.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: You're always carrying a tray.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I'm taking a drink over to the negroes in the barn.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: I'll do that. I can't get much wetter.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: Mr. Inman.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Reverend.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: What can I do for you?

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: I have some sheet music. Belonged to my father. No use to me.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: You must come in.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: I should probably get along.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Mr. Inman is more comfortable outdoors. Perhaps we might take a walk.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: A splendid idea.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: I want to get sheep into this field. A big field doesn't look right without sheep. You're a lucky fellow, Mr. Inman, you've had this view all your life.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: I think so.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: It's a special view. I dragged my poor daughter to Cold Mountain from Charleston because of my Doctors -- they say my heart is weak -- so the air's meant to do me good. But it's the view I think heals.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: I have to get on my visits. Can I offer you a ride back into town?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Well, you have your war.

Speaker: teague
Dialogue: Those who follow Lincoln, or preach abolition, best keep one eye open when they're sleeping, Old Bogey Man might get you!

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Are you the law all of a sudden?

Speaker: teague
Dialogue: That's right, son. Home Guard for Haywood County. I'm the law from today. You all go fight now. We'll watch your sweethearts.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: You might be safer back in Charleston.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: But then who'll be waiting for you?

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: I'm going to walk back inside the Chapel.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: Did you want a quiet word?

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Just some quiet.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: Of course Ada.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: I'll daresay Dr. O'Brien'll want to do a test or two.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: And then there'll be a coffee or two, a brandy or two...

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I found you this book. William Bartram. They tell me it's good. I think he writes about these parts, the author, so...

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: And this...  I'm not smiling in it. I don't know how to do that, hold a smile, so now I'm solemn...

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Ada...

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: rourke
Dialogue: Let's go!

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: I'm not dying.

Speaker: stobrod
Dialogue: What'd he say?

Speaker: pangle
Dialogue: Says he ain't about to die.

Speaker: stobrod
Dialogue: Truth to tell they say you are, Soldier. We'll meet again, in the better world.

Speaker: teague
Dialogue: My condolences to you all.  Keep an eye on the negro. They want what the white man got -- all of you watch out your brave boys give their lives to war and meantime your slaves carry murder, rape and arson to your firesides.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: The only slaves within twenty miles labor on my farm. They're good Christians and I'll vouchsafe for them.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: You're looking -- at this moment, I don't know why -- you're looking exactly like your mother.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Every time you see the doctor you get melancholy.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: He listens to my heart and I get emotional.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: He gives you alcohol and you get emotional.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: We commiserate about the folly of this terrible war.  From Mr. Inman?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Yes. But then I've tried counting the number of words which passed between Mr. Inman and me.  Is that a bonfire? So close to the barns.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: What's going on?

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: Hey! Stop there! Hey!

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: Dear God.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: No, Daddy, it's not real.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: What is wrong with us all?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I'll get help.  Keep away from the flames.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Most of these men will be dead by the morning or, if they're stubborn, by nightfall. I have other men outside in the quadrangle waiting for the beds.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: So, any kind word will be a blessing.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: It's the heat. I'm sorry. They rot.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Don't pray. If they're not God fearing you can stir up a hornet's nest.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Pigeon River. Little East Fork.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: They ramble. Names of loved ones.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: This man is dead.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: Thank you.  For your Providence, Oh lord, we thank you.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Amen. That was the last of the ham.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: It was delicious.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I have to learn how to cook.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: I was going to say something in Chapel. Perhaps some of the womenfolk will volunteer.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I can't have people coming here and cooking for me!

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: It's my fault. I should have raised you less like a companion and more like a young woman. I'm sorry.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I'm not sorry, but I don't know how we'll get through another winter.

Speaker: monroe
Dialogue: Will you play me something? Something peaceful while I look over my sermon.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Daddy, bring the tablecloth in with you!

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Daddy, come inside before you drown!

Speaker: official
Dialogue: -- Any man takes in a deserter is likewise guilty of treason.

Speaker: official
Dialogue: The Home Guard is powered to enter any place it sees fit, without notice or constraint. Names of all deserters will be posted in every town, published in every newspaper.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Is there a letter for me?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I know. Thank you so much.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: What do you hear?

Speaker: teague
Dialogue: It's taken me too long, but I've come to pay my respects.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: teague
Dialogue: I reckoned you might need fattening up.

Speaker: teague
Dialogue: This house must bring bad luck. Killed my granddaddy to lose it, then my daddy died on account of not having it, then your daddy died on account of getting it. We should burn it down.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Didn't somebody try?

Speaker: teague
Dialogue: Lot to manage without help. Need a hand with that pump?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: teague
Dialogue: I'm happy to volunteer.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: But not to volunteer for the war?

Speaker: teague
Dialogue: The war? I wanted to go. But you know: too old, too literate. Plus I got no spleen. Lost it from a horse's kick.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: You've got no spleen.

Speaker: teague
Dialogue: That's the thing about an organ. You don't know you need it till you lost it.  I want to clear this path. I can just as soon do it and talk as stand around and talk. Then you can say men beat a path to your door.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I'd really prefer it if you didn't do that.

Speaker: teague
Dialogue: Would you rather I did my job?  See if there's any material I should confiscate. For the war effort.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I was raised in the good manners of the South where a gentleman doesn't enter a house with a woman alone.

Speaker: teague
Dialogue: And you're sleeping all right? These cold dark nights?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I'm sleeping fine.

Speaker: teague
Dialogue: It's going to be a long hard winter.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Ada! Ada, It's Sally.

Speaker: esco
Dialogue: Will you look at the state of this place!

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Poor soul. She's got nobody and nothing and three hundred acres of misery.

Speaker: blind man
Dialogue: Getting better all the time.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Seems that way.

Speaker: blind man
Dialogue: I wouldn't hurry. War's almost done.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Where'd you take your wound?

Speaker: blind man
Dialogue: Before I was born. Never saw a thing in this world, not a tree a gun or a woman. Though I put my hand on all three. Couple of things I felt back there I'd sure liked to have had a long look at.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: What would you give for that? To have your eyeballs back for ten minutes?

Speaker: blind man
Dialogue: Ten minutes! Wouldn't give an Indian head cent. I fear it might turn me hateful.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: That's sure what seeing's done to me.

Speaker: blind man
Dialogue: That ain't the way I meant it. You said ten minutes. It's having a thing and then the loss I'm talking about.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Then we don't agree. There's not much I wouldn't give for ten minutes of someplace.

Speaker: blind man
Dialogue: Someplace or someone.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Same difference.

Speaker: blind man
Dialogue: You watch yourself. They're shooting men who take themselves a walk.

Speaker: barber
Dialogue: Next.

Speaker: barber
Dialogue: I'll cut your hair, but I ain't about to shave you. That thing opens up, your head's liable to falloff.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: You're skinny as a whippet, girl -- you're coming indoors with me.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I can't. I'm not -- I need to clean some clothes.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Great God, you ever looked at my husband! I can't get him to wear decent Church clothes Christmas morning. Hang on to me, the wind'll blow you over.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: Don't go back to that dark house. There's a bed here, least till our boys get home.

Speaker: esco
Dialogue: That your daddy's coat?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I was saying to Sally, I wasn't expecting to be visiting, so...

Speaker: esco
Dialogue: Don't suit you.

Speaker: esco
Dialogue: I can't get up to your place this week.  She's mad at me --

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I don't expect -

Speaker: esco
Dialogue: -- more than I can do to keep this place half-managed. I'm ready-to stop, I tell you. I just want to sit on my porch with Sal, watch my boys in the field, holler good job! every hour or so.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: What about your people in Charleston?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: There are no people. And no money. My father had some bonds and investments. They're worthless now, of course, the war has... they're not worth anything.  I love it here. In spite of everything.

Speaker: esco
Dialogue: And waiting on a feller.

Speaker: esco
Dialogue: Look down our well.  You do it! Don't make that face.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: I know it ain't rightly Christian, but it's what folks do, like when they dangle a needle over the belly to see if you're carrying a boy or a girl.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: What kind of mirror?

Speaker: esco
Dialogue: See anything?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: I tried many a time, never saw a dickybird.

Speaker: sally
Dialogue: You all right?

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: If that letter ain't urgent, the cow is -- is what I'm saying.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I don't know you.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Old Lady Swanger says you need some help. Here I am.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I need help, I need, I do need help, but I need a laborer -- there's plowing and rough work and -- I think there's been a misunderstanding.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: What's the rake for?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: The rake?

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Ain't for gardening, that's for sure. Number one -- you got a horse I can plow all day. I'm a worker. Number two there's no man better than me cause there's no man around who ain't old or full of mischief. I know your plight.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: My plight?

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Am I hard to hear cause you keep repeating everything. I'm not looking for money, never cared for it and now it ain't worth nothing. I expect to board and eat at the same table. I'm not a servant. Do you get my meaning?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: You're not a servant.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: People'll have to empty their own night jars, that's my point.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: And I'm not planning to work while you watch neither.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Is that a yes or a no?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: There's half the day yet. Let's make a start. My name's Ruby. I know your name.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: The rake: there's a rooster devil, I'm sure of it. He's Lucifer himself. I go near him he's at me with his spurs.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: I despise a flogging rooster. Where is he?

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Let's put him in a pot.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Hey!  I'd pay a dollar for an egg. A piece of cheese.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Ada? Ada? You up?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Yes.  It's still dark.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Tell the cows that. It's late.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I have to eat something.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Then you have to get up earlier.  What's that?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: A novel.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: You want to carry a book carry one you can write in --

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: -- we got our own story. Called Black Cove Farm: a catastrophe.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: I can spell it, too. C-a-t-a-s-t-r-o- phe. Learned the same place you did, in the schoolroom. That's one of the first words they taught me. Ruby Thewes, you are a ca-t-a-s-t-r-o-p-h- e...

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: You mucking out?

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Three years I was in school before my daddy -- saying God rest his soul is like wishing him what he had in life, cause he lived to rest, he was born tired -- before my daddy decided there was better use for my backside than have it sat all day in front of a blackboard.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Number One -- layout a winter garden for cool season crops: turnips, onions, cabbage, greens.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Number Two: patch the shingles on the barn roof. Do we have a maul and froe?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Maul?

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: M-a-u-l.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I have no idea.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Number three: clay crocks for preserves. Tomatoes. Beans. Jams.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Clear and turn this field. No harm done letting it go fallow, now we'll do well.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Number fifteen

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Sixteen.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Number sixteen: let's get a martin colony going in the Gourd House. Keep away crows. You got one thing in abundance on this farm and that's crows.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: What's a Gourd House?

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: There's survival. On them trees.  You got a cider press or would that be wishing on a blessing?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Actually, yes, I think we do.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Don't let go. Just back up, nice and steady, do this all in reverse, you're going to end up with her draped back over your animal.

Speaker: veasey
Dialogue: Don't pull that trigger. I am a man of God.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: I've killed several of them.

Speaker: veasey
Dialogue: I mean I am God's minister.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: What part of God's business is throwing a woman down a gorge.

Speaker: veasey
Dialogue: A slave woman, can you see that in this light? She's black as a bucket of tar.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Is she dead?

Speaker: veasey
Dialogue: Drugged her. Like you would a butterfly. And I care for her, that's the heartbreak of it.

Speaker: veasey
Dialogue: She's got my bastard in her belly. What kind of pistol is that I never saw the like of it?

Speaker: veasey
Dialogue: I'm begging you. It's better you blowout my brains than return me to this place.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Where does she live?

Speaker: veasey
Dialogue: In our house. She sleeps in our kitchen. You don't know me, friend, but the good Lord punished me with want. I am all appetite. That's all I do all day is want: food, the female parts...

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Shut your mouth. I don't want a sermon every time I ask a question.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: This your place?

Speaker: veasey
Dialogue: Dear God of misery.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: You're going to put her back where she sleeps.

Speaker: veasey
Dialogue: I do that the Members will lynch me. Consorting with a nigger, adultery, siring a bastard while serving as their preacher. We're a strict congregation we've churched men for picking up a fiddle on the sabbath.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: So you reckoned to kill her.

Speaker: veasey
Dialogue: There's a back door. Have pity.

Speaker: veasey
Dialogue: Thank you. I was going to do a grievous wrong.

Speaker: vesey
Dialogue: You tasted dark meat? Sweet as liquorice. I think I should go back up to my wife. She wakes at the slightest noise.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: You find me some paper and a pen.

Speaker: veasey
Dialogue: You're not entitled to judge me! You're nothing but an outlier, plain as daylight!

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Morning. Pigs: you have any loose in the woods?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: No. What? No. We bought our hams.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: There's a world more to a hog than the two hams! Lard, for example, we'll need plenty --

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: The catastrophe of Ada Monroe's laundry.  I can feel you shutting your eyes.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: What's this wood?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I don't know. Locust?

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Where's North?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: North is, North is --

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Name me three herbs growing wild on this farm.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: I can't! I can't! All right? I can talk about farming in Latin. Will that do? I can read French. I know Harmony and Counterpoint. I know my Bible. I can name the principal rivers of Europe, but don't ask me to name one stream in this county. I can embroider, but I can't darn, I can arrange cut flowers, but I can't grow them. If a thing has a function, if I might do something with it, it wasn't considered suitable.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: Ruby, you could ask why? about pretty much everything to do with me.

Speaker: ada
Dialogue: This fence is about the first thing I've ever done that'll produce an actual result.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: So you never wrapped your legs around this Inman?

Speaker: ferrygirl
Dialogue: For five dollars I wouldn't give a parched man a dipper of this riverwater.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: Sign says ferry, five dollars.

Speaker: ferrygirl
Dialogue: This look like a ferry? My Daddy's dead, or gone off to the Federals, don't matter which. I'm the way across now.

Speaker: inman
Dialogue: What's the name of this thing?

Speaker: ferrygirl
Dialogue: Nothing but the mighty Cape Fear River, is all.

Speaker: ferrygirl

Dialogue: Oh Ruby.

Speaker: ruby

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: There's cows to milk.

Dialogue: Why you in such a hurry the whole time?  Hurry or slow the destination is always the same. It's only the journey that is different. That's either in the Good Book or I made it up.

Speaker: veasey
Dialogue: Good day to you!

Dialogue: This is a tricky one.

Dialogue: How do you work this damn thing?

Dialogue: Come on.

Dialogue: Let's do this in chapters.

Dialogue: You might want to leave off that water for a day or two.

Dialogue: There'll be a tang, I'd imagine.

Speaker: veasey
Dialogue: Looks a bit crooked.

Dialogue: -- Roll me over!

Dialogue: Like a Christian.

Dialogue: Good God.

Dialogue: What?

Dialogue: With that trap.

Dialogue: You know it.

Dialogue: Ruby...

Dialogue: You tell Ada that was a good pie.

Dialogue: Different fighting.

Dialogue: Mister -- you could fix me I'd be in your everlasting debt.

Dialogue: You're quiet.

Dialogue: I bargained like Lucifer. We can make all kinds of good eating.

Dialogue: Never knew a man worked in his field with a shotgun.

Dialogue: There's a war on.

Dialogue: Got to watch out for the Bogey Man.

Dialogue: Your boys come back.

Dialogue: So you won't care if we take a look around?

Dialogue: Sure.

Dialogue: Right then.

Dialogue: Hey!

Dialogue: You got your bait. Set it on the hook.

Dialogue: So you've been fighting?

Dialogue: Swallow it. If you die I'll give you your money back.
